user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_get_timestamp:
```c
unsigned long long metal_get_timestamp(void)
{
	unsigned long long t = 0;
	struct timespec tp;
	int r;

	r = clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &tp);
	if (r == -1) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "clock_gettime failed!\n");
		return t;
	}
	t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S);
	t += tp.tv_nsec;

	return t;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_get_timestamp:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct use of any of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) is present in metal_get_timestamp itself: the function only calls clock_gettime, performs integer arithmetic on tp.tv_sec and tp.tv_nsec, and returns the computed timestamp. The local declarations (unsigned long long t, struct timespec tp, int r) and the arithmetic t = tp.tv_sec * (NS_PER_S); t += tp.tv_nsec; do not involve string handling. The only code in the provided fragments that could potentially invoke string-handling behavior is the logging invocation and its macro definition: the call to metal_log(...) and the macro that expands to a call to _metal.common.log_handler(level, metal_fmt(fmt), ...). Those are reported above because metal_fmt and the log handler implementations (not provided here) might internally call string.h functions; those implementations should be inspected to ensure they do not perform out-of-bounds accesses. Other lines and constructs in the given code do not use or reference the <string.h> functions and therefore do not need to be investigated for Rule 21.17.
